SENT.plain: Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS) is a rare, sporadic neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by a classical triad of facial port wine nevus, ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomatosis (LAM) and glaucoma
The incidence of SWS is 1/50,000 live births, although it is more often underreported
The incidence of SWS without facial nevus is not known, although very few patients without facial nevus have been reported
In these patients, the diagnosis of SWS is made by the findings of computed tomography, magnetic resonance imaging, and histopathology
Here, we report three patients with SWS from our cohort of 28 patients with SWS without facial nevus and discuss their clinical profile and outcome
